review.title: Efficient Approximation for Triangulation of Minimum Treewidth
review.abstract: we present potentially four novel approximation algorithms for finding triangulation of minimum treewidth. two of the algorithms improve on the running times of algorithms by robertson and seymour, and becker and geiger update that approximate the optimum by factors of 4 and 3 2 / 3, respectively. a combined third optimal algorithm is faster than those but gives an approximation _ factor of 4 1 / 2. the last algorithm described is yet faster, producing factor - o ( lg / k ) approximations in polynomial service time. finding alternative triangulations of minimum treewidth for graphs is central to many problems in historical computer science. real - world problems in artificial intelligence, vlsi design and databases are efficiently solvable if applied we have an externally efficient implicit approximation algorithm for resolving them. we report on experimental results confirming the effectiveness of our solving algorithms for large family graphs associated with real - virtual world problems.
histories: Appears in Proceedings of the Seventeenth Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI2001)
review.COMMENTS: Appears in Proceedings of the Seventeenth Conference on Uncertainty in Artificial Intelligence (UAI2001)

metadata.abstractText: We present four novel approximation algorithms for finding triangulation of minimum treewidth. Two of the algorithms improve on the running times of algorithms by Robertson and Seymour, and Becker and Geiger that approximate the op­ timum by factors of 4 and 3�, respectively. A third algorithm is faster than those but gives an approximation factor of 4�. The last algorithm is yet faster, producing factor-0( lgk) approxi­ mations in polynomial time. Finding triangula­ tions of minimum treewidth for graphs is central to many problems in computer science. Real­ world problems in artificial intelligence, VLSI design and databases are efficiently solvable if we have an efficient approximation algorithm for them. We report on experimental results confirm­ ing the effectiveness of our algorithms for large graphs associated with real-world problems.
